metadata.name: Language Data Commons Comprehensive Collection
metadata.description: Implements the language data commons RO-Crate Metadata Profile for the top-level, objects and files.
metadata.author: University of Queensland

inputGroups.name: About
inputGroups.help: The core metadata for this RO-Crate and its subject matter.

inputGroups.name: Related People, Orgs & Works
inputGroups.help: The context for the creation of this RO-Crate; who made it, funded it etc.

inputGroups.name: Structure
inputGroups.help: For groups of elements, such as DefinedTerms.

inputGroups.name: Provenance
inputGroups.help: Detailed description of how entities were created, by whom and with which tools.

inputGroups.name: Language
inputGroups.help: Metadata related to the languages used, modes of communication and other linguistic classifications.

inputGroups.name: Space & Time
inputGroups.help: Where and when the data was collected; the times and places it mentions or describes.

inputGroups.name: Software & Hardware
inputGroups.help: For computer programs and execution environments that could be used to create data, have created data, or are being packaged and described.

inputs.name: isAccessibleForFree
inputs.help: This is available under an Open Access license.

inputs.name: name
inputs.help: The name of this dataset.

inputs.name: license
inputs.help: Link to a document that describes the rights and obligations for users of this collection record. NOTE: This does not necessarily cover the license terms that may apply to Objects in the collection which may have specific licensing. Licensing on other objects overrides the license attached to a collection record.

inputs.name: ldac:annotationOf
inputs.help: This resource contains some kind of description that adds information to the resource it references.

inputs.name: dct:rightsHolder
inputs.help: The person or organisation owning or managing rights over the resource.

inputs.name: isBasedOn
inputs.help: Link to or description of an original resource.

inputs.name: creditText
inputs.help: A free text bibliographic citation for this material, e.g. 'Cite as: Musgrave (2023). Title of work. DOI'.

inputs.name: usageInfo
inputs.help: Additional information on licensing options for using the data, e.g. 'Contact the Data Steward to discuss license terms'.

inputs.name: author
inputs.help: The person or organisation responsible for creating this collection of data. Authors should be identified using URIs such as ORCiD or ROR.

inputs.name: accountablePerson
inputs.help: The person or organisation who is the data steward for this resource.

inputs.name: publisher
inputs.help: The organisation responsible for releasing this dataset.

inputs.name: funder
inputs.help: The organisation(s) responsible for funding the creation or collection of this dataset.

inputs.name: citation
inputs.help: Associated publications.

inputs.name: description
inputs.help: An abstract of the collection. Include as much detail as possible about the motivation and use of the dataset, including things that we do not yet have properties for.

inputs.name: ldac:doi
inputs.label: DOI
inputs.help: A Digital Object Identifier, e.g. https://doi.org/10.1000/182.

inputs.name: temporalCoverage
inputs.help: The range of years of creation for items in this dataset using a slash, e.g. 1900/1945. If there are sub-collections with different coverages put this on the sub-collections not the top-level.

inputs.name: spatialCoverage
inputs.help: The place(s) that are the focus of the content. It is a sub-property of contentLocation intended primarily for more technical and detailed materials. For example, with a dataset, it indicates areas that the dataset describes: a dataset Cape York languages would have spatialCoverage which was the place: the outline of the Cape.

inputs.name: ldac:hasCollectionProtocol
inputs.help: A link to a CollectionProtocol object with (at least) a summary of how resources were selected or elicited for this collection/sub-collection.

inputs.name: pcdm:hasMember
inputs.help: The sub-collections, if any, associated with this collection.

inputs.name: hasPart
inputs.help: An item or CreativeWork that is part of this item, or CreativeWork (in some sense).

inputs.name: isPartOf
inputs.help: An item or CreativeWork that this item, or CreativeWork (in some sense), is part of.

inputs.name: pcdm:memberOf
inputs.help: Links from a Repository Object or Collection to a containing Repository Object or Collection.

inputs.name: datePublished
inputs.help: The (earliest) date this work was created.

inputs.name: ldac:annotator
inputs.help: The participant produced an annotation of this or a related resource.

inputs.name: ldac:compiler
inputs.help: The participant is responsible for collecting the sub-parts of the resource together.

inputs.name: ldac:consultant
inputs.help: The participant contributes expertise to the creation of a work, for example by contributing knowledge of their native language.

inputs.name: ldac:dataInputter
inputs.help: The participant responsible for entering, re-typing, and/or structuring the data contained in the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:depositor
inputs.help: The participant responsible for depositing the resource in an archive.

inputs.name: ldac:developer
inputs.help: The participant developed the methodology or tools (including software) that constitute the resource, or that were used to create the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:editor
inputs.help: The participant reviewed, corrected, and/or tested the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:illustrator
inputs.help: The participant contributed drawings or other illustrations to the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:interpreter
inputs.help: The contributor renders the discourse recorded in the resource into another language in real time, or the contributor explains the discourse recorded in the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:interviewee
inputs.help: The participant was a respondent in an interview.

inputs.name: ldac:interviewer
inputs.help: The participant conducted an interview that forms part of the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:participant
inputs.help: The participant was present during the creation of the resource, but did not contribute substantially to its content.

inputs.name: ldac:performer
inputs.help: The participant performed some portion of a recorded, filmed, or transcribed resource. It is recommended that this term be used only for creative participants whose role is not better indicated by a more specific term, such as 'speaker', 'signer', or 'singer'.

inputs.name: ldac:photographer
inputs.help: The participant took the photograph, or shot the film, that appears in or constitutes the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:recorder
inputs.help: The participant operated the recording machinery used to create the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:researcher
inputs.help: The resource was created as part of the participant's research, or the research presents interim or final results from the participant's research.

inputs.name: ldac:researchParticipant
inputs.help: The participant acted as a research subject or responded to a questionnaire, the results of which study form the basis of the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:responder
inputs.help: The participant was an interlocutor in some sort of discourse event, but only reacted to the contributions of others.

inputs.name: ldac:signer
inputs.help: The contributor was a principal signer in a resource that consists of a recording, a film, or a transcription of a recorded resource. Signers are those whose gestures predominate in a recorded or filmed resource. (The resource may be a transcription of that recording).

inputs.name: ldac:singer
inputs.help: The participant sang, either individually or as part of a group, in a resource that consists of a recording, a film, or a transcription of a recorded resource.

inputs.name: ldac:speaker
inputs.help: The contributor was a principal speaker in a resource that consists of a recording, a film, or a transcription of a recorded resource. Speakers are those whose voices predominate in a recorded or filmed resource. (The resource may be a transcription of that recording).

inputs.name: ldac:sponsor
inputs.help: The participant contributed financial support to the creation of the resource.

inputs.name: ldac:transcriber
inputs.help: The participant produced a transcription of this or a related resource.

inputs.name: ldac:translator
inputs.help: The participant produced a translation of this or a related resource.

inputs.name: contentLocation
inputs.help: The location depicted or described in the content. For example, the location in a photograph or painting.

inputs.name: conformsTo
inputs.help: A link to the language data commons RO-Crate profile for collections.

inputs.name: inLanguage
inputs.help: The language in which the resource is written.

inputs.name: ldac:subjectLanguage
inputs.help: The languages that the materials in the collection are about (not the language that it is in).

inputs.name: description
inputs.help: A description of the item.

inputs.name: datePublished
inputs.help: The (earliest) date this work was created.

inputs.name: temporalCoverage
inputs.help:
The temporalCoverage of a CreativeWork indicates the period that the content applies to, i.e. that it describes, either as a DateTime or as a textual string indicating a time period in [ISO 8601 time interval format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Time_intervals). In
      the case of a Dataset it will typically indicate the relevant time period in a precise notation (e.g. for a 2011 census dataset, the year 2011 would be written "2011/2012"). Other forms of content, e.g. ScholarlyArticle, Book, TVSeries or TVEpisode, may indicate their temporalCoverage in broader terms - textually or via well-known URL.
      Written works such as books may sometimes have precise temporal coverage too, e.g. a work set in 1939 - 1945 can be indicated in ISO 8601 interval format format via "1939/1945".

Open-ended date ranges can be written with ".." in place of the end date. For example, "2015-11/.." indicates a range beginning in November 2015 and with no specified final date. This is tentative and might be updated in future when ISO 8601 is officially updated.

inputs.name: identifier
inputs.help: The identifier property represents any kind of identifier for any kind of [[Thing]], such as ISBNs, GTIN codes, UUIDs etc. Schema.org provides dedicated properties for representing many of these, either as textual strings or as URL (URI) links. See [background notes](/docs/datamodel.html#identifierBg) for more details.

inputs.name: name
inputs.help: The name of this work.

inputs.name: description
inputs.help: An abstract of the work.

inputs.name: author

inputs.name: ldac:annotationOf
inputs.help: This resource contains some kind of description that adds information to the resource it references.

inputs.name: ldac:annotationType
inputs.help: The type of an Annotation resource.

values.description: The resource describes the gestural content of the resource it annotates.
values.name: ldac:Gestural

values.description: The resource contains annotations using orthography (a writing system) as opposed to a coded representation such as a phonetic transcription.
values.name: ldac:Orthographic

values.description: An annotation that assigns lexical elements of language to classes on the basis of their distributional properties (for sign languages, the term 'sign class' is appropriate).
values.name: ldac:PartOfSpeech

values.description: An annotation that represents speech in terms of the sound contrasts made in a language.
values.name: ldac:Phonemic

values.description: A representation of speech in terms of the sounds produced, typically using the International Phonetic Alphabet.
values.name: ldac:Phonetic

values.description: An annotation that includes information about the sound system of a language, such as the contrasts between sounds which make up the sound system and the locally conditioned realisations of sounds which characterise speech in the language.
values.name: ldac:Phonological

values.description: An annotation that provides a symbolic record of intonation, stress, tone or other suprasegmental features, which is expressed independently of regular phonetic transcription.
values.name: ldac:Prosodic

values.description: The resource includes annotation or analysis concerning the encoding of meaning.
values.name: ldac:Semantic

values.description: The resource contains annotation or analysis describing the combinatorial patterns of words in another resource.
values.name: ldac:Syntactic

values.description: The resource contains a transcription, which is a written representation (orthographic or coded) of an audio or visual signal.
values.name: ldac:Transcription

values.description: This is a translation of a resource in another language.
values.name: ldac:Translation

inputs.name: ldac:annotator
inputs.help: The participant produced an annotation of this or a related resource.

inputs.name: ldac:channels
inputs.help: The number of audio channels this resource contains (e.g. 1, 2, 5.1).

inputs.name: ldac:communicationMode
inputs.help: The mode (spoken, written, signed etc.) of this resource. There may be more than one value for this property.

values.description: The resource contains non-linguistic gestural communication (i.e. not sign language).
values.name: ldac:Gesture

values.description: The resource contains data for which the medium of interaction was signing.
values.name: ldac:SignedLanguage

values.description: The resource contains data for which the medium of interaction was song.
values.name: ldac:Song

values.description: The resource contains data for which the medium of interaction was speech.
values.name: ldac:SpokenLanguage

values.description: The resource contains data for which the medium of interaction was whistling.
values.name: ldac:WhistledLanguage

values.description: The resource contains data for which the medium of interaction was writing.
values.name: ldac:WrittenLanguage

inputs.name: ldac:interviewer

inputs.name: ldac:isDeIdentified
inputs.label: Is De-identified
inputs.help: The data in this item has had potentially identifying information removed, which may include replacing names with pseudonyms.

inputs.name: isbn
inputs.label: ISBN
inputs.help: The ISBN for this work, if applicable.

inputs.name: issn
inputs.label: ISSN
inputs.help: The ISSN for this publication.

inputs.name: ldac:linguisticGenre
inputs.help: A linguistic classification of the genre of this resource.

values.description: An interactive discourse with two or more participants. Examples of dialogues include conversations, interviews, correspondence, consultations, greetings and leave-takings.
values.name: ldac:Dialogue

values.description: A planned, creative rendition of discourse with two or more participants intended for presentation to an audience.
values.name: ldac:Drama

values.description: The resource is a ritually or conventionally structured discourse.
values.name: ldac:Formulaic

values.description: Discourse whose primary purpose is to inform the audience about the natural or social world.
values.name: ldac:Informational

values.description: The resource is a conversation where one or more speakers are directing the conversation.
values.name: ldac:Interview

values.description: The resource includes a systematic listing of lexical items.
values.name: ldac:Lexicon

values.description: Language whose primary function is to be part of play, or a style of speech that involves a creative manipulation of the structures of the language. Examples of ludic discourse are play languages, jokes, secret languages, and speech disguises.
values.name: ldac:Ludic

values.description: A discourse, monologic or co-constructed, which represents temporally organised events. Types of narratives include historical, traditional, and personal narratives, myths, folktales, fables, and humorous stories.
values.name: ldac:Narrative

values.description: The art of public speaking, or of speaking eloquently according to rules or conventions. Examples of oratory include sermons, lectures, political speeches, and invocations.
values.name: ldac:Oratory

values.description: An explanation or description of a method, process, or situation having ordered steps.
values.name: ldac:Procedural

values.description: A factual account of some event or circumstance.
values.name: ldac:Report

values.description: The resource contains a list or data structure consisting of words or concepts arranged according to sense.
values.name: ldac:Thesaurus

inputs.name: ldac:mainText
inputs.help: Identifies the most relevant sub-component for computational text analytics.

inputs.name: ldac:material
inputs.help: Description of the original media, e.g. audio cassette tapes, participant questionnaires, field notes.

inputs.name: ldac:openAccessIndex
inputs.help: One or more public index types allowed by a license, e.g. FullText indexing may be allowed for discovery even when an item is not.

values.description: A text index that makes the full text of a data resource findable via a search interface.
values.name: ldac:FullText

inputs.name: ldac:orthographicNotes
inputs.help: A description of the specific orthographic writing system(s) used in the material (e.g. Latin, Cyrillic, Australian English, IPA), or particular conventions required to understand the material (e.g. O* = ).

inputs.name: ldac:writtenLanguageFormat
inputs.help: The format of the resource resulting from the way the text was produced (handwritten, typeset, typewritten).

values.description: The resource was written using a writing implement such as a pen, pencil, brush or computer stylus (except where the digital handwriting is converted to standard text).
values.name: ldac:Handwritten

values.description: The resource has been formatted for printing or display.
values.name: ldac:Typeset

values.description: The resource contains text produced on a typewriter.
values.name: ldac:Typewritten

inputs.name: name
inputs.help: The name of this protocol.

inputs.name: author
inputs.help: The person or organisation responsible for creating this collection of data. Authors should be identified using URIs such as ORCiD or ROR.

inputs.name: description
inputs.help: A summary of the collection protocol used for this collection or sub-collection, e.g. how texts were selected, or what prompts were given to participants.

inputs.name: ldac:collectionProtocolType
inputs.help: A description of the process used to collect or collate data, such as prompts given to participants, or how texts are selected for inclusion in a collection.

values.description: The collection protocol includes a task-based prompt to participants.
values.name: ldac:ElicitationTask

values.description: A description of the criteria used to select texts in a collection.
values.name: ldac:MaterialSelectionCriteria

inputs.name: datePublished
inputs.help: The (earliest) date the collection protocol was published.

inputs.name: name
inputs.help: The name of the place.

inputs.name: description
inputs.help: A description of the place.

inputs.name: address
inputs.help: The physical address of the place.

inputs.name: geo
inputs.help: The geographic coordinates of the place.

inputs.name: asWKT
inputs.help: The WKT serialisation of the geometry.

inputs.name: name
inputs.help: The name of the person.

inputs.name: description
inputs.help: Add any additional information not covered by other properties here.

inputs.name: affiliation
inputs.help: The organisation that this person is affiliated with. For example, a university or school.

inputs.name: ldac:age
inputs.help: The age or age range of a person, e.g. 25, 30-50, >50. If an age is specified, a prov:specializationOf pointing to a 'canonical' ageless version of that Person can also be included.

inputs.name: ldac:isDeIdentified
inputs.label: Is De-Identified
inputs.help: The data in this item has had potentially identifying information removed,  which may include replacing names with pseudonyms.

inputs.name: name
inputs.help: The name of the organisation.

inputs.name: description
inputs.help: A description of the organisation.

inputs.name: location
inputs.help: A location for the organisation, e.g. a city for a publisher.

inputs.name: encodingFormat
inputs.help: The media type typically expressed using a MIME format.

inputs.name: ldac:communicationMode
inputs.help: The mode(s) (spoken, written, signed, etc.) used in the interaction represented by this resource.

values.description: The resource contains non-linguistic gestural communication (i.e. not sign language).
values.name: ldac:Gesture

values.description: The resource contains data for which the medium of interaction was signing.
values.name: ldac:SignedLanguage

values.description: The resource contains data for which the medium of interaction was song.
values.name: ldac:Song

values.description: The resource contains data for which the medium of interaction was speech.
values.name: ldac:SpokenLanguage

values.description: The resource contains data for which the medium of interaction was whistling.
values.name: ldac:WhistledLanguage

values.description: The resource contains data for which the medium of interaction was writing.
values.name: ldac:WrittenLanguage

inputs.name: name
inputs.help: The name of the item.

inputs.name: license
inputs.help: A license document that applies to this content, typically indicated by URL.

inputs.name: ldac:linguisticGenre
inputs.help: A linguistic classification of the genre of this resource.

values.description: An interactive discourse with two or more participants. Examples of dialogues include conversations, interviews, correspondence, consultations, greetings and leave-takings.
values.name: ldac:Dialogue

values.description: A planned, creative rendition of discourse with two or more participants intended for presentation to an audience.
values.name: ldac:Drama

values.description: The resource is a ritually or conventionally structured discourse.
values.name: ldac:Formulaic

values.description: Discourse whose primary purpose is to inform the audience about the natural or social world.
values.name: ldac:Informational

values.description: The resource is a conversation where one or more speakers are directing the conversation.
values.name: ldac:Interview

values.description: The resource includes a systematic listing of lexical items.
values.name: ldac:Lexicon

values.description: Language whose primary function is to be part of play, or a style of speech that involves a creative manipulation of the structures of the language. Examples of ludic discourse are play languages, jokes, secret languages, and speech disguises.
values.name: ldac:Ludic

values.description: A discourse, monologic or co-constructed, which represents temporally organised events. Types of narratives include historical, traditional, and personal narratives, myths, folktales, fables, and humorous stories.
values.name: ldac:Narrative

values.description: The art of public speaking, or of speaking eloquently according to rules or conventions. Examples of oratory include sermons, lectures, political speeches, and invocations.
values.name: ldac:Oratory

values.description: An explanation or description of a method, process, or situation having ordered steps.
values.name: ldac:Procedural

values.description: A factual account of some event or circumstance.
values.name: ldac:Report

values.description: The resource contains a list or data structure consisting of words or concepts arranged according to sense.
values.name: ldac:Thesaurus

inputs.name: contentSize
inputs.help: File size in (mega/kilo)bytes.

inputs.name: hasPart
inputs.help: An item or CreativeWork that is part of this item, or CreativeWork (in some sense).

inputs.name: publisher
inputs.help: The publisher of the creative work.

inputs.name: creator
inputs.help: The creator/author of this CreativeWork. This is the same as the Author property for CreativeWork.

inputs.name: datePublished
inputs.help: The (earliest) date this work was created.

inputs.name: temporalCoverage
inputs.help:
The temporalCoverage of a CreativeWork indicates the period that the content applies to, i.e. that it describes, either as a DateTime or as a textual string indicating a time period in [ISO 8601 time interval format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Time_intervals). In
      the case of a Dataset it will typically indicate the relevant time period in a precise notation (e.g. for a 2011 census dataset, the year 2011 would be written "2011/2012"). Other forms of content, e.g. ScholarlyArticle, Book, TVSeries or TVEpisode, may indicate their temporalCoverage in broader terms - textually or via well-known URL.
      Written works such as books may sometimes have precise temporal coverage too, e.g. a work set in 1939 - 1945 can be indicated in ISO 8601 interval format format via "1939/1945".

Open-ended date ranges can be written with ".." in place of the end date. For example, "2015-11/.." indicates a range beginning in November 2015 and with no specified final date. This is tentative and might be updated in future when ISO 8601 is officially updated.

inputs.name: inLanguage
inputs.help: The language in which the resource is written.

inputs.name: ldac:subjectLanguage
inputs.help: The languages that the materials in the collection are about (not the language that it is in).

inputs.name: dateCreated
inputs.help: The date on which the CreativeWork was created or the item was added to a DataFeed.

inputs.name: ldac:materialType
inputs.help: Indicates whether the material in a file is the original (primary) source or is derived from it or describes it via annotation.

values.description: The object of study, such as a literary work, film, or recording of natural discourse.
values.name: ldac:PrimaryMaterial

values.description: The resource includes material that adds information to some other linguistic record.
values.name: ldac:Annotation

values.description: This is derived from another source, such as a Primary Material, via some process, e.g. a downsampled video or a sample or an abstract of a resource that is not an annotation (an analysis or description).
values.name: ldac:DerivedMaterial

inputs.name: ldac:derivationOf
inputs.help: This property references another resource from which the current resource is derived, e.g. downsampling audio or video files, or extracting text from a PDF.

inputs.name: ldac:hasDerivation
inputs.help: This property references another resource that is derived from it, such as a downsampled audio or video file, or text extracted from a PDF.

inputs.name: ldac:collectionEventType
inputs.help: A kind of CollectionEvent characterised by some specific procedures, e.g. a psycholinguistic experiment.

values.description: A collection event that is a recording or elicitation session with participants.
values.name: ldac:Session

inputs.name: ldac:reviewDate
inputs.help: The date that this license should be reviewed.

inputs.name: ldac:access
inputs.help: Whether this is an open or restricted access license.

values.description: Indicates that a DataReuseLicense requires some kind of authorization step, from SelfAuthorization (click-through) to processes that require a data steward to grant permission.
values.name: ldac:AuthorizedAccess

values.description: Data covered by this license may be accessed as long as the license is served alongside it, and does not require any specific authorization step.
values.name: ldac:OpenAccess

inputs.name: ldac:accessControlList
inputs.help: When a license has an authorizationWorkflow property with a value of the DefinedTerm AccessControlList this property has a URI value that points to a list of userIDs.

inputs.name: ldac:authorizationWorkflow
inputs.help: By what process a user is granted authorization to a license.

values.description: License grants access to data based on a list of approved users, specified using the property accessControlList.
values.name: ldac:AccessControlList

values.description: A user is expected to explicitly agree to a set of license terms, this may be combined with AccessControlList - to note that even if a user has been pre-approved for a license they must agree to license terms.
values.name: ldac:AgreeToTerms

values.description: Users may apply for a license via some workflow, such as a form, with the decision being made by a DataSteward or their delegate about whether to grant the license.
values.name: ldac:AuthorizationByApplication

values.description: A data steward or administrator is expected to use an access control system to invite users, for example, participants, collaborators or students.
values.name: ldac:AuthorizationByInvitation

values.description: A user can be authorised to access data by clicking that they agree to a license, or filling out a form to check their understanding, which can be validated by a machine and does not require human intervention.
values.name: ldac:SelfAuthorization
